												Miles Logan is a jewel thief. Things go awry while he's stealing a huge diamond in downtown L.A.: a thief, Deacon, tries a double-cross, the police arrive, and Miles is arrested, but not before he hides the jewel in an air duct of a building under construction. Two years later, he's out of prison and he heads for the site: it's L.A.'s new police headquarters! Posing as a reassigned cop, Miles gets into the building, but before he can recover the swag, he's partnered with a naive detective and sent out to investigate burglaries. With Deacon on his trail, he must recover the diamond, keep the cops fooled, and do a few good deeds as a detective who can think like a criminal.

18, 2015
												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it made reviews too long to submit from time to time, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery. Also, this review will be written with respect to Half-Life and Opposing Force, so there are spoilers ahead for those two.Gameplay: Half-Life 1 had some interesting things, Opposing Force had the same interesting things but with even more interesting things. Blue Shift has less things in it than even Half-Life 1. Calling this an expansion pack is, to be quite frank, something of an insult to Opposing Force. You don't even get all of the human arsenal, let alone ANY the alien arsenal. Enemy design has gone back as well; you fight a total of six different types of enemies throughout this "expansion" pack. There aren't even any bosses!  Level design is... well, it's alright. Nothing too impressive, but nothing really worth slandering. The big kicker is the fact that I beat it in just over two hours, not even dying once on Normal Mode (apart from a not so good platforming section). It feels like something of a fan project as opposed to the quite frankly stellar performance put forward in making Opposing Force. This was two years later, so there really was no excuse. 5/10.Story: Well, maybe the story makes up for it? Not really. You're a security guard, some things happen and you exit Black Mesa. No intrigue whatsoever; hell, the G-Man makes one appearance. That's it. Definitely another disappointment. 4/10.Graphics: Yet another step back from Opposing Force. Even after just having beaten it, I'm struggling to remember anything about the Black Mesa complex's area design apart from the final "area" of the game. You go to Xen which is neat and all, but again; it just feels like more of the same. It's just as technically adept as Opposing Force, so I don't really have any complaints there. It's just that the area design feels so damn lackluster. 3/5.Sound: There's a couple of songs for the OST which are relatively intense and used for all of ten seconds, leaving you feel kinda unfulfilled. Voice acting is just alright now that there's no G-Man, and the sound design is pretty much on the same level as Opposing Force. 3/5.Overall scores are: 5/4/3/3; cumulative score of 5.0/10. Out of the "main" Half-Life 1 series, play Half-Life 1 and Opposing Force. If you really wanna see what this one is about, just watch a speedrun. It'll save you an hour and a half and about $5. Really, really lackluster.

												Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion that was to be exclusive to the cancelled Dreamcast port of the original Half-Life. That game was cancelled, but the game lives on, with HD textures, and a third narrative to the Black Mesa Incident. This time, you are everyones favorite security officer and beer-ower, Barney Calhoun. While the weapons are the same, with a few left out, you do get another oppertunity to gun down hordes of Xen aliens and marine soldiers. It's a cheap game, so you should pick it up if you crave Half-Life, or it goes on sale. Seriously, I got it for $1.24 in a sale, and it was worth it.EDIT: Forgot to mention a couple things. One, the game is a lot more puzzle based than the others. Two, the game is much shorter than the others, with no real end boss either.

												Miles Logan is a jewel thief. Things go awry while he's stealing a huge diamond in downtown L.A.: a thief, Deacon, tries a double-cross, the police arrive, and Miles is arrested, but not before he hides the jewel in an air duct of a building under construction. Two years later, he's out of prison and he heads for the site: it's L.A.'s new police headquarters! Posing as a reassigned cop, Miles gets into the building, but before he can recover the swag, he's partnered with a naive detective and sent out to investigate burglaries. With Deacon on his trail, he must recover the diamond, keep the cops fooled, and do a few good deeds as a detective who can think like a criminal.

												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it made reviews too long to submit from time to time, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery. Also, this review will be written with respect to Half-Life and Opposing Force, so there are spoilers ahead for those two.Gameplay: Half-Life 1 had some interesting things, Opposing Force had the same interesting things but with even more interesting things. Blue Shift has less things in it than even Half-Life 1. Calling this an expansion pack is, to be quite frank, something of an insult to Opposing Force. You don't even get all of the human arsenal, let alone ANY the alien arsenal. Enemy design has gone back as well; you fight a total of six different types of enemies throughout this "expansion" pack. There aren't even any bosses!  Level design is... well, it's alright. Nothing too impressive, but nothing really worth slandering. The big kicker is the fact that I beat it in just over two hours, not even dying once on Normal Mode (apart from a not so good platforming section). It feels like something of a fan project as opposed to the quite frankly stellar performance put forward in making Opposing Force. This was two years later, so there really was no excuse. 5/10.Story: Well, maybe the story makes up for it? Not really. You're a security guard, some things happen and you exit Black Mesa. No intrigue whatsoever; hell, the G-Man makes one appearance. That's it. Definitely another disappointment. 4/10.Graphics: Yet another step back from Opposing Force. Even after just having beaten it, I'm struggling to remember anything about the Black Mesa complex's area design apart from the final "area" of the game. You go to Xen which is neat and all, but again; it just feels like more of the same. It's just as technically adept as Opposing Force, so I don't really have any complaints there. It's just that the area design feels so damn lackluster. 3/5.Sound: There's a couple of songs for the OST which are relatively intense and used for all of ten seconds, leaving you feel kinda unfulfilled. Voice acting is just alright now that there's no G-Man, and the sound design is pretty much on the same level as Opposing Force. 3/5.Overall scores are: 5/4/3/3; cumulative score of 5.0/10. Out of the "main" Half-Life 1 series, play Half-Life 1 and Opposing Force. If you really wanna see what this one is about, just watch a speedrun. It'll save you an hour and a half and about $5. Really, really lackluster.

												Saying if this game is better or worse than the other 2 Half-Lifes is a difficult task. I played all 3 approximately at the same time, and none differ mechanically in any way. They work the same.So the difference is in setting in length and here it's a good news/bad news situation. Good news is ; the storytelling and setting is significantly improved. Not that there was much higher HF could go in that respect, but you get to interact ever so briefly with NPCs in a way that lends them more personality and interacting with Dr. Rosenberg later on is actually well done. Bad news is, it's much shorter and not nearly as challenging. But since it comes with a bundle and is cheap as chips anyway, I recommend it as an added, well designed HF experience.

												If you like the original Half Life, you'll also like Blue Shift.  It's a very similar game, with the same type of action and puzzles (and even the same weapons).  Many of the same enemies return as well, both from Xen and Marines.  If you haven't played the original Half Life, I'd recommend starting there instead.  Both have excellent gameplay, but you get more of the story in the original.I'd recommend Opposing Force over Blue Shift, however.  Both are the same price, but Opposing Force is about twice as long, and is also a much more innovative expansion, with interesting new weapons and levels that differ more from the original than Blue Shift's.  Blue Shift itsn't bad by any means, it just doesn't add new content to the series in the way Opposing Force does.

, 2014
												Half Life: Blue Shift is simple, short, and to the point. It's not some grandiose adventure that has you killing an alien mastermind, it's not you stopping an unlimited power from destroying mankind, it's just a guy running away from danger with a few allies. The mapping is solid, the combat is challenging, there are even a few secrets here and there, but I believe the best thing about this is that the levels set in Xen are extremely fun. Unlike in the original Half Life where they felt tacked on, or in Opposing Force where they were basically easter eggs. On a  less positive note, this expansion limits you to only nine weapons, but in a way, this is also a plus as it simplifies your equipment. Though, there goes the beegun, the gluon gun, the gauss cannon, etc etc. Another unsavory thing is that armor is rare; since you wear security armor you can only scavenge from fallen guards such as yourself, there's no suit recharging, which can leave you quite vulnerable.Besides one completely ridiculous puzzle (at least for me, that is), it is extremely fun and engaging. But be warned, this is the shortest Half-Life expansion, in fact, it doesn't even have multiplayer, so if you're looking for something a bit longer (or with multiplayer action) I'd recommend Opposing Force.

												Having played the main story for the Half-Life series years ago, I wanted to play the lesser known Half-Life: Blue Shift.  After finishing it, I didn't find it as fun as I thought it would be but that's mostly because of bugs.  Now the bugs may actually be from the original Blue Shift, it may have came along with the steam port, or I'm simply too used to Valve's more recent games, but either way here are my complaints.- Pressing the use key "E" stops the player from moving, and pressing it repeatedly makes your character stutter.  If you miss grabbing an object and try to grab it again, you will stutter.- Pressing the use key on an object and pressing left or right launches the object at a high speed, sometimes dragging you along with it.- Whenever loading a saved game, attack is almost always on auto, so if you have a crowbard you'll keep swinging until you press attack again.  If you saved with your gun as your weapon, you'll autmatically be shooting when loaded.- Loading spots can sometimes be near an enemy, so if you're moving back and forth to shoot the enemy, you'll keep on loading and lagging.- Not necessarily a bug but there are some things that look like you can crouch jump onto but actually can't.When there are obstacles that involve moving objects around, it becomes kind of frustrating.  I guess the only directions you should use is just forwards and backwards when grabbing things.If you can get past over these it's not a bad game, but not that interesting either.  I would recommend if you're interseted in another perspective on the Black Mesa incident.

												Half-Life: Blue Shift is essentially a DLC pack for the original Half-Life game.  However, it contains enough content and play-time, that is was launched standalone.Half-Life: Blue Shift puts you not in the shoes of the familiar Gordon Freeman from the original game itself, but instead in the shoes of one of the Black Mesa security guards.  You participate in your own adventure that parallels Freemans in the main game, with a few interwoven connections, but the story is truly unique.  You even have a similar run-in with the infamous G-Man as well.I would recommend this game to anyone who has played the original Half-Life game and is interested in the story of Black Mesa.

er 24, 2014
												This is the definitive Half-Life experience, vanilla Half-Life gameplay at its finest and core Half-Life gameplay elements at their most refined.I just recently finished recorded my playthrough of this game and i am currently uploading my playthrough of Opposing Force unto Youtube (at the time of this review).This game was supposed to be a Sega Dreamcast exclusive but because of how underrated the Dreamcast was, it just became a PC exclusive and it worked out well.Released 3 years after Half-Life was released and 2 years after Opposing Force was released, the GoldSrc Engine was looking a bit dated so they released a High Definition Model Pack along side Blue Shift and it was optional to install and in this release (SteamPipe Release at the time that this review was written) you can just tick a check box in your graphics section on your options menu to enable and disable it and the HD Model Pack is now available for Half-Life and Opposing Force without needing to buy Blue Shift and now they fixed the HUD Color Bug which was in the previous Steam version of this game.Based upon the time on my playthrough videos, Half-Life is about 10 to 12 hours to playthrough.Based upon the time on my playthrough videos, Opposing Force is about 6 to 8 hours to playthrough.Based upon the time on my playthrough videos, Blue Shift is about 4 to 6 hours to playthrough.Valve and Gearbox did a excellent job making this game.Back in the day when this game was first released, it would have not have been worth the price unless you did not have Opposing Force which was also included with the WON (Pre-Steam) Release of this game but since it is cheap on Steam then i recommend this game but i would rather recommend just buying the Half-Life 1 Anthology Pack or buying a used copy of the WON Release of Half-Life for cheap and attempt to register it on Steam by activating the CD Key and hope that it works rather than buying this game standalone.Star Rating: 4.0 Out of 5

r 3, 2014
												Compared to the original game and the first expansion pack : Opposing Force ; Blue Shift doesn't do justice to the Half-Life name in terms of gameplay. As Opposing Force sets the bar high, Blue Shift does little in terms of gameplay and weapons.The story is good and short, you play as Barney Calhoun (the very same from HL2), who is a Black Mesa security personel and gets caught in the Resonance Cascade.7/10 'Okay', worth playing for the story and if you're a Half-Life dedicated fan.

r 4, 2014
												A competent addition to the Half-Life series which helps shed light on what happened to many of the other characters in the events during the original Half-Life. While it lacks the depth and length of Opposing Force, it takes the tools available to it, and makes a solid game out of it. I'll admit a couple puzzles went a little bit strange with their solutions, but apart from that it's a decent extra for those interested in extending their playtime by another two or three hours while also getting some good storyline.

r 12, 2013
												Another entry to the Half-Life franchise, Blue Shift once again takes the player to Black Mesa. This game, although rather short, puts you in the shoes of Barney Calhoun, as he struggles to escape from the Black Mesa Research Facility, after his good ol' friend, Gordon Freeman, not only messed up the facility, but also asked him to pay for that beer he owed him.All joking aside, this game packs the same action as Half-Life and Opposing Force, although in a much shorter package. While some people have complained about its length, I think it's perfect, since making it longer wouldn't add much more to it. Highly recommended.

ry 24, 2015
												This was an interesting game as you got to experience the Black Mesa incident from the perspective of Barney Calhoun, a Black Mesa security officer. If you don’t remember him, he was briefly seen in the beginning of the original game. If you've played Half-Life 2 already, but haven't played this expansion, it will show you how he made it out of there alive, not to mention a few other things that weren’t seen by Gordon Freeman. Although it's relatively short, it's a great game and has the same feeling as the original Half-Life.

18, 2012
												Definitely a must-buy with the actual Half-Life 1 and the other "DLC", Opposing Force. Blue Shift takes the point-of-view of the Balck Mesa accident through Barney's eyes (The combine in disguise from HL2) who is a security worker at Balck Mesa. Great storyline, just as good weapons and some amazing fast-paced shooting, Blue Shift is a must buy. 9.5/10

Suddenly, a mall cop shows up and pistol whips all the aliens.
